statement.tex:
%text For what value of $k$ would % \qquad f(x) = \begin{cases} kx + 1,\, x\leq 5 \\ 3x-5,\, x\gt 5 \end{cases} %text
be continuous at $x=5$? %

options.tex:
%text The value of $f(x)$ for $x = 4.9,5,5.1$ would be as follows
% \qquad \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline x & f(x) \\ \hline 4.9 & 4.9k + 1 \\ \hline 5 & 5k + 1 \\ \hline 5.1 & 3(5.1) - 5=10.3 \\ \hline \end{tabular}

%text The value of $f(x)$ for $x = 4.9,5,5.1$ would be as follows
% \qquad \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline x & f(x) \\ \hline 4.9 & 4.9k + 1 \\ \hline 5 & 3(5) - 5 = 10 \\ \hline 5.1 & 3(5.1) - 5=10.3 \\ \hline \end{tabular}

reason.tex:
%text For $x\leq 5$, $f(x) = kx + 1$. Hence, even for $x=5, f(x) = kx + 1 = 5k+1$
But for $x\gt 5, f(x) = 3x + 1$. Which is why $f(x) = 3(5.1) - 5 = 10.3$ for $x = 5.1$. %

options.tex:
%text For $f(x)$ to be continuous at $x = 5$, the following must be true
\[ \qquad 5k + 1 = 10 \implies k = \frac{9}{5} \] %

reason.tex:
%text For $f(x)$ to be continuous \[ \qquad \lim_{x\to 5^-}f(x) = \lim_{x\to 5^+} f(x) = f(5) \]
Which means, % \begin{align} \lim_{x\to 5^-} (kx+1) &= \lim_{x\to 5^+} (3x-5) = \underbrace{5k+1}_{f(5)}\\ \text{or } 5k + 1 &= 3(5) - 5 = 10 \\ \therefore k &= \frac{10 - 1}{5} = \frac{9}{5} \end{align} %text
Hence, $f(x)$ is continuous at $x=5$ if $k = \frac{9}{5}$ %
